description: Borrowed into Middle English from Old French duresse, from Latin duritia (“hardness”), from durus (“hard”).

entries.meaning: (law) Restraint in which a person is influenced, whether by lawful or unlawful forceful compulsion of their liberty by monition or implementation of physical enforcement; legally for the incurring of civil liability, of a citizen's arrest, or of subrogation, or illegally for the committing of an offense, of forcing a contract, or of using threats.

verbs.description: duress (third-person singular simple present duresses, present participle duressing, simple past and past participle duressed)

entries.meaning: To put under duress; to pressure.
examples: The small nation was duressed into giving up territory.
